timeline.message: removed AbstractFlagEncoder.speedDefault and flagsDefault() and EncodingManager.flagsDefault()

timeline.bodyText: Hm I think for tests like this graph.edge(a, b, dist, bidir) was quite useful? Can we not keep it somehow?
timeline.author: easbar

replies.author: easbar

replies.bodyText: It is not easy as the information which encoder should be used is required.
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText: Ah true we would need GHUtility.edge(graphHopperStorage...) then. Hm, maybe we do not need this after all when we tweak the GHUtility method(s) a bit (see other comments).
replies.author: easbar

timeline.bodyText:
The name of this method seems rather confusing. The old setProperties method should probably be called setAccessAndSpeed? And this new one just sets the access and speed for all encoders, but uses half the max speed as speed? So its something like setAccessAndHalfTheMaxSpeedForAllEncoders?
Btw. what I also think is confusing is that we have graph.edge(a, b) and not graph.edge(a, b, dist). Do we ever need an edge without a distance? Maybe distance should go in these setProperties kind of methods as well then?
timeline.author: easbar

replies.bodyText:
Ah, ok. Sure.

Do we ever need an edge without a distance?

Yes. Yes, for barrier nodes and I think also for certain PT edges we do not set and need a distance.
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText:
What is the reason for speed=maxspeed/2?

Yes. Yes, for barrier nodes and I think also for certain PT edges we do not set a distance.

For barrier nodes there is a distance (its just  zero). For PT I am not sure. But if its just zero (but exists in storage) also for PT I would rather add the distance parameter and set it to zero than have this setDistance() method. Even when we do not have it we could add graph.edge(a, b, dist) additionally?
replies.author: easbar

replies.bodyText:
What is the reason for speed=maxspeed/2?

Some arbitrary speed we use to initialized this. Similar to flagEncoder.speedDefault before. But surely we can get rid of this. See my comment below.

For PT I am not sure. But if its just zero (but exists in storage) also for PT I would rather add the distance parameter

What I meant is that distance is just an edge property like speed and for certain edges of an time-expanded model in PT the distance property does not make sense, not even 0.
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText:
What I meant is that distance is just an edge property like speed

Yes excepts its not stored in flags?

for certain edges of an edge-expanded model in PT the distance property does not make sense, not even 0.

This is interesting because it means we could save memory for PT if we removed the distance field (if this is relevant in any way).
Would it be a problem to add graph.edge(a, b, dist)?
replies.author: easbar

replies.bodyText:
Yes excepts its not stored in flags?

Currently an implementation detail :D

This is interesting because it means we could save memory for PT if we removed the distance field (if this is relevant in any way).

Yes, definitely. (btw it is time-expanded not edge-expanded like I said before)

Would it be a problem to add graph.edge(a, b, dist)?

Not sure. IMO it is not a method that belongs to the Graph interface.
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText: Ok convinced, lets keep it as is and use setDistance().
replies.author: easbar

timeline.bodyText: What I like here is that the speed is now explicit, while previously one always had to keep in mind that its 60 in these tests. Maybe I just have to get used to this verbose code to create a testing graph, but also see my other comment about setProperties which I do not find intuitive.
timeline.author: easbar

replies.bodyText: I also do not find it intuitive and for tests we should think about a better solution. Maybe we can use the method you proposed above but with a GraphHopperStorage which gives us access to the EncodingManger where we then by default use car access and average_speed?
replies.author: karussell

timeline.bodyText: We should probably run code formatting here. For example you can undo all changes and commit them again with the "format  on commit" checkbox enabled in intellij.
timeline.author: easbar

replies.bodyText: Ok, will do. (I usually do not use IntelliJ for git)
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText: I just meant this is an easy way to apply the formatting to the changed files only. I think we never fixed the formatting for the entire project so its hard to run it everywhere ;)
replies.author: easbar

timeline.bodyText: I am not sure yet if this is an improvement compared to several calls to setProperties? Especially setting speed=maxspeed/2  seems not very obvious (or maybe I do not understand it yet)?
timeline.author: easbar

replies.bodyText:
The idea was basically to have an alternative to the previously used graph.edge(from, to, dist, bothDir) (like you said before it was pretty useful). So we set some default speed for all encoders. And maxspeed/2 is approximatively the previously used default speed for all encoders.
We should rename the method as a first step. But I'm unsure if we should make it more explicit as it will then get more verbose?
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText: Can we not just remove it entirely? I think most tests use a single encoder anyway? And for those that do not maybe we can add a helper method there? The problem with maxspeed/2 is that its some kind of 'convention' that one a) has to know and b) couples otherwise unrelated tests to each other. Changing this later would affect many tests and at the same time there is no real reason it is maxspeed/2 and not e.g. maxSpeed/3.
replies.author: easbar

replies.bodyText: What do you want to remove entirely? The method? I would rather expand its usage and make speed+encoder more explicit? I like it more as the edge creation is less hidden within GHUtility calls.
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText:
What do you want to remove entirely? The method?

Yes, GHUtility.setProperties(List<EdgeIteratorState>... and setting maxspeed/2 . Its only used in three places.
Then creating edges could look like this:
EdgeIteratorState edge = GHUtility.setAccessAndSpeed(graph.edge(3, 5, 200), encoder, true, false, 60);
or maybe even (not sure)
EdgeIteratorState edge = graph.edge(3, 5, 200).setAccessAndSpeed(encoder, true, false, 60))
or
EdgeIteratorState edge = graph.edge(3, 5).setDistance(200).set(accessEnc, true).setReverse(accessEnc, false).set(speedEnc, 60).setReverse(speedEnc, 60);
?
replies.author: easbar
easbar

replies.bodyText: I think I favor the last option I proposed because it is very explicit and not even that verbose. I am just not sure how set(encValue, boolean, boolean) behaves for encoded values that do not support two different directions (like road_class). Would we be able to throw an error when we call set(encValue, fwd, bwd), encValue is not bidirectional and fwd!=bwd, something like set(roadClassEnc, true, false)? <- should be ok see previous comment
replies.author: easbar

replies.bodyText:
set(encValue, boolean, boolean)

Sounds like a good solution.

I am just not sure how set(encValue, boolean, boolean) behaves for encoded values that do not support two different directions

This should work the way you described

Its only used in three places.

Only because I introduced it very late in the process as I stumbled over the fact that often multiple edges are initialized with the same speeds and IMO this "bulk" method improves readability of the edge creation.
What about a method like:
setSpeeds(Double fwdSpeed, Double bwdSpeed, FlagEncoder encoder, EdgeIteratorState... edges)
It is short and less verbose for many edges.
And it would be already compatible to a version without "access"-bits. With that I mean the following: currently we have the "access"-bits defined only to use less bits (2 bits + speed bits intead of 2*speed_bits) and something that only the Weighting can define. Hmmh, or before or additionally to #1835 it might be interesting to investigate if we in general move away from access bits and just use 2*speed_bits? So for higher precision of 7 bits this means 5 bits more per vehicle profile but even for hiking or walking this would make sense (#1679). Not sure.
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText:
setSpeeds(Double fwdSpeed, Double bwdSpeed, FlagEncoder encoder, EdgeIteratorState... edges)

Where would you put this method and can you give an example for its usage?

And it would be already compatible to a version without "access"-bits.

Ah because fwd/bwdSpeed=infinity would mean 'no access'?

if we in general move away from access bits

This is a hard question, but so far it seems useful to me to e.g. separate motorized and outdoor profiles even without specifying the weighting already. Is this something we have to decide here? My guess is the refactoring here will not make it harder to remove the access flags later. So yes we can introduce a helper method that already hides them, but we can just as well do this when we actually make this move? Delaying this until later seems to be the better option to me because we do not really know what we will do yet :)
replies.author: easbar
karussell

replies.bodyText: Ok, either way seems fine. Is it a lot of work to turn the single edge creations into calls to (GHUtility.setSpeeds(fwdSpeed, bwdSpeed, encoder, EdgeIteratorState...)? I am happy with this format and maybe only use GHUtility.setSpeeds later in places we feel it makes sense?
replies.author: easbar

replies.bodyText:
Yes, it is a lot of work to migrate the current stuff. Probably we should follow a similar approach like migrating to junit5 :)

I am happy with this format

Should I introduce the methods set(encValue, fwd, bwd) in this PR or later?
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText:
Yes, it is a lot of work to migrate the current stuff. Probably we should follow a similar approach like migrating to junit5 :)

I agree.

Should I introduce the methods set(encValue, fwd, bwd) in this PR or later?

Is it harder or easier to search/replace GHUtility.setProperties here than it would be to search/replace graph.edge and do change it to set(encValue, fwd, bwd) in master? Hm yes why not do it here directly?
replies.author: easbar
karussell

replies.bodyText:
Except we set the backward value in a silent manner

Yeah that's not ideal, for example setting .set(speedEnc, 60, 40) should be an error if there is only one direction?
And I guess you right if we do just search&replace we a) do not know if the encoder is bidirectional and b) we do not even know if speed=60 is correct because that depends on the encoder? But maybe we can assume its a car encoder with one direction and speed 60 and only fix the remaining (hopefully not so many) cases?

So for now I would prefer to keep it (simpler?) like:

Yes sure if it makes the refactoring easier I would also use the utility method for now.
replies.author: easbar

replies.bodyText:
Yes sure if it makes the refactoring easier I would also use the utility method for now.

Yes, this 'regex refactoring' was relative time intense :)
replies.author: karussell

timeline.message: introduce methods ala edge.set(ev, fwd, bwd)
strict handling for new edge.set(enc, fwd, bwd) method
use bulk setSpeed in some more places
reduce usage of setReverse with new set method

timeline.bodyText: Why did you add the speed parameter here? The previous behavior was that the default speed was used if randomSpeedEnc was null and random speeds were generated otherwise. In case randomSpeedEnc.isStoreTwoDirections different speeds were used for fwd/bwd direction. Ok now the default speed is gone we need some speed parameter (or just set it to 60 inside this method?), but we should still use random speeds were we did before. Right now speed is != null almost everywhere. Also its a bit problematic to change this method because it might break older seeds (that we should not rely on, but I think in some cases we still do...)
timeline.author: easbar

replies.bodyText:
I did not intend to change this and tried to be careful ... likely I misunderstand something. The intention was to call with speed=null where before it was called with randomSpeedEnc=null.

Right now speed is != null almost everywhere.

Only for EdgeBasedTarjanSCCTest there were calls with randomSpeedEnc=null. Those two calls are done via speed=null now.

Also its a bit problematic to change this method because it might break older seeds

Hmmh, random.nextDouble() is still called regardless of whether it is used like before. For me currently it is not obvious where I changed behaviour. Probably we need a test for this :) ? I'll have a look as you observed behaviour change due to this in #1631

but we should still use random speeds were we did before

I checked twice but if speed is null the speeds are random (which also feels more logical than before).
Edit: ah, maybe the default speed for motorvehicle was not 60?
Edit: no, it was also 60, like for car
replies.author: karussell

replies.bodyText:
I did not intend to change this and tried to be careful ...

Yeah, I saw. When I reviewed this I also checked and thought its the same. But now I realized that once we set speed != null we always have fwdSpeed==bwdSpeed, while before we had fwdSpeed!=bwdSpeed in case speedEnc!=null 🙄 ... Ugh I will have a look again tomorrow ;)
replies.author: easbar
